p.s: Gatsby is characterized as hopeful and loving.
He is finally not alone anymore.
The weather functions as a symbol.
The scene reveals a new side of Gatsby.
Up to this point Nick's perception and opinion of Gatsby fluently changes.
Firstly Gatsby is characterized as very mysterious and gossiped about.
At his first appearance in the novel, he is merely seen from the behind standing alone on his lawn, reaching out towards the green light on the dock on the other side.
In the third chapter is revealed, that there are many rumours and much gossip about him, causing Nick to be suspicious of him and wanting to meet him.
At the party Nick has a conversation with Gatsby.
Even amongst so many people, Gatsby is portrayed as alone: my eyes fell on Gatsby, standing alone [...] looking from one group to another (p. 51 l. 19f.).
At that moment Nick could see nothing sinister about him (p. 51 l. 22).
Later his opinion of Gatsby changes, when Gatsby tells him about his apparent past: I was sorry I'd ever set foot upon his overpopulated lawn (p. 67 l. 19f.), regretting having met Gatsby.
At the end of the given excerpt Gatsby is described very positive and happy in such a way, that is has an effect on his surroundings.
He literally glowed; without a word or a gesture of exultation a new well-being radiated from him and filled out the little room(p. 87 l. 14f.).
GatsbysGatsby's characterization in this chapter stands in contrast to the previous ones.
He is described as alone twice and he lives alone in his mansion.
Even at parties he doesn't drink: I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests (p. 51, l. 23f.).
Gatsby is shown as different from his guest and seperatedseparated from them.
In contrast to this in the fifth chapter, where he is with Daisy he is characterized very differently.
In the beginning of the scene he is very nervous, why he leaves NicksNick's house.
This extreme nervousness is underlined by the simile pale as death (p. 84 l. 14).

Later in the room he is still nervous and tries to build a facade of calm and ease to conceal how unsure he is: his hands still in his pockets, was reclining against the mantelpiece in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease, even of boredom (p. 84 l. 27f.).
When he is alone with Nick he drops his facade: and whispered 'Oh God' in a terrible way (p. 85 l. 30f.).
Gatsby'sGatsby's plan is not working out exactly as he had planned so he is stressed.
This is a terrible mistake [...] a terrible, terrible mistake(p. 87 l. 1f.).
Gatsby's repetition of the term terrible mistake highlights his desperation and revealreveals his facade to Nick and the reader.
The fact that Daisy might be embarrassed as well, never crossed his mind and astonishes him.
'She's embarrassed?' he repeated incredulously(p. 86 l. 5), shows that Gatsby is overwhelmed with the situation and takes the blame for the awkwardness of the situation.
When Nick leaves and later comes back Gatsby is characterized very differently: He literally glowed (p. 87 l. 14).
He has overcome the tension and has reconnected with Daisy, which he has been waiting to do for years.
With this he has partly achieved what he wanted to achieve.
In contrast to the former presentations of Gatsby, he now is happy and also not alone anymore.
This is underlined by the setting and the weather.
The rain has stopped, as well as the tension between the two.
But not only that, he has also reconnected with Daisy again after five years.
The sun and light stand for optimism.
But later on in the chapter the rains continues again implicating that this time with Daisy was only temporary.
NicksNick's cottage symbolizes a place, where wealth doesn't matter, apart from the mansion.
The stories narrator is Nick and he characterizes Gatsby.
So the reader can only view Gatsby through his eyes.

In this case his narration contributes to the way Gatsby is characterized, because if Daisy was the narrator, Gatsby would be percievedperceived very differently, as she was very overwhelmed with the situation.
Nick is not part of the reunion, so he can judge the event as an outstander.
One scene he is not in the room but eavesdroppes and so the reader can only percieveperceive the scene through hearing.
Here emphasis is put on the sound and not the visual elements leading the reader to concentrate on different things.

Nick claims to be very honest: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known (p. 60 l. 11f.) but this statement is contradicted a few times as he is sugarcoating events anand leaving things out.
So the reader still has to reflect Nick's perception of Gatsby.
In this excerpt Gatsby reunites with Daisy and is characterized as very happy.
he can finally show his true colours and has achieved, what he has been waiting for.
The setting aswell as Nick as the narrator play into the peceptionperception of Gatsby in this scene.
